But for people who munch on a few snack foods a day, trans fats can add up incrementally.
Lynn Browne is a professor of food science at Penn State University.
She says researchers have tested just how little trans fat it takes as a percentage of your overall calorie intake to do damage.
They found that 3.8 percent of the calorie intake was sufficient to raise LDL.
That's the bad cholesterol.
So in a 2,000 calorie diet the 3.8 percent translates to about eight grams of fat.
So what's the chance you'd actually eat that much in a day?
Well, it would take a serious cookie binge - say, a teenager wolfing down a whole package of cookies, or an adult who has coffee cake in the morning, cookies with lunch and some fries at dinner.
The good news is that across the board — from fast food chains to processed snack foods - trans fats have been reduced in the American food supply by more than 50 percent in the last several years.
